author: agemanning
content:
Hey all. 
An increasing number of users are reporting a strange phenomenon. We find our external ip/port based on the majority of PONG responses we receive. 
We're finding that pong responses are returning alternating ports. i.e A single node is receiving PONG's with portA and portB which is making it difficult to find the external ip/port. 
This indicates that the router is sending outbound packets on two different ports, which is confusing. 

Another theory, would be that an implementation is returning a different port other than the origin of the packet, maybe using the ENR or some other thing? Wondering if anyone else has seen this and/or if there may be anything strange in the PONG port responses in implementations?

author: nishant0
content: of the peers returning from alternating ports from their outbound packets

author: agemanning
content: No, user's haven't been that detailed. I will be investigating soon tho

author: nishant0
content: ok thanks, for informing. Will take a look from my end too , to see if we see anything wierd

author: nishant0
content: is this a recent development ? was this noticeable in the older testnets

author: agemanning
content: Yeah. I've seen it reported a few times before, but wasn't significant enough with the other things we were dealing with. But now there are more reports, so time to look into it

author: nishant0
content: I tried looking through our discovery logs and unfortunately couldnt find any inbound packets from remote peers fitting that description
